I'm going to try something new here: I'll talk about some stuff I'm thinking about, and see if anyone has questions or has something to say. If you don't understand what I'm saying, please ask questions! If you know stuff about this topic, I'd like to hear it!

(On other forums I'm getting disappointed with how few people talk about my posts.)

Given a functor F:A→XF : A \to XF:A→X, any object x∈Xx \in Xx∈X has a "homotopy fiber", where an object is an object a∈Aa \in Aa∈A together with an isomorphism α:F(a)→x\alpha: F(a) \to xα:F(a)→x, and a morphism is 'the obvious thing' (explanation available on request).

This is the obvious sort of categorification of when you have a function between sets, any point in the codomain has a 'fiber' or 'inverse image' consisting of all points in the domain that map to it.
I guess more technically this homotopy fiber is the 'isocomma object' of F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X and G:1→XG: 1 \to XG:1→X, where GGG is the functor that picks out the object XXX.
I'm interested in certain examples these days. Generalizing from these examples we get this:

Suppose you have algebras AAA and BBB over some field and a homomorphism f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B. Then you get adjoint functors between their categories modules AModA\mathsf{Mod}AMod and BModB\mathsf{Mod}BMod: 'restriction along fff'

f∗:BMod→AModf^\ast : B\mathsf{Mod} \to A\mathsf{Mod}f∗:BMod→AMod

and its left adjoint which I guess might be called 'extension along fff'.

f∗:AMod→BModf_* : A\mathsf{Mod} \to B\mathsf{Mod}f∗​:AMod→BMod
This sends any AAA module MMM to the BBB-module B⊗AMB \otimes_A MB⊗A​M where BBB becomes a right AAA-module using f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B.
So what I'm interested in are the homotopy fibers of f∗f^\astf∗ and f∗f_\astf∗​ in some really concrete examples.
The homotopy fiber of f∗f^*f∗ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the category of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".
The homotopy fiber of f∗f_\astf∗​ is intuitively "the category of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".
I'm following so far, but isn't there another adjoint that you could add to this picture? Is restriction along f also cocontinuous?
(Specifically, I'm expecting HomA(M,B)\mathrm{Hom}_A(M,B)HomA​(M,B) to provide the right adjoint)
I'm interested by the "explanation available on request" on what is an homotopy fiber.

John Baez said:

The homotopy fiber of f∗f_*f∗​ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the set of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".

The homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ is intuitively "the set of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".

Aren't those reversed?

As a topologist and topos theorist, I'm used to f∗f_*f∗​ denoting a right adjoint of f∗f^*f∗, which as Morgan mentioned also exists here ("coextension of scalars"); I would write f!f_!f!​ for the left adjoint of f∗f^*f∗. I know that algebraic geometers have different conventions; is f∗f_*f∗​ commonly used for extension of scalars?

Anyway, as for your question, the obvious first class of examples that occurs to me is when A=kA=kA=k is the field itself. Then the f∗f^*f∗-fiber over a vector space MMM is the set of BBB-module structures on it.

Mike Shulman said:

The homotopy fiber of f∗f_*f∗​ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the set of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".

The homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ is intuitively "the set of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".

Aren't those reversed?

Yes, fixed.

Mike Shulman said:

As a topologist and topos theorist, I'm used to f∗f_*f∗​ denoting a right adjoint of f∗f^*f∗, which as Morgan mentioned also exists here ("coextension of scalars"); I would write f!f_!f!​ for the left adjoint of f∗f^*f∗. I know that algebraic geometers have different conventions; is f∗f_*f∗​ commonly used for extension of scalars?

I don't know what the hell different people do with all this f∗,f∗,f!f^\ast, f_\ast, f_!f∗,f∗​,f!​ notation - I find it incredibly confusing. Different people seem to do different things. I'm using f∗f^\astf∗ here because an algebra homomorphism f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B is giving rise to a functor going "backwards", f∗:AMod→BModf^\ast : A\mathsf{Mod} \to B \mathsf{Mod}f∗:AMod→BMod.

(So, we're getting a contravariant functor from some category of algebras to some category of some very nice categories, and when we get everything running really smoothly, perhaps adding some side conditions if necessary, it becomes a contravariant equivalence of bicategories.)

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

I'm following so far, but isn't there another adjoint that you could add to this picture? Is restriction along f also cocontinuous?

There probably is another adjoint quite generally, but in fact I'm working with semisimple algebras, whose categories of (finite-dimensional) modules are semisimple categories, and this seems to ensure that the that my left adjoint f∗f_\astf∗​ is also a right adjoint to f∗f^\astf∗. So in my particular context I've got an [[ambidextrous adjunction]], which is very fun but makes it unnecessary to roam the land looking for further adjoints.
I should add that I'm interested in really specific features of really specific examples, so I haven't put much effort into improving my overall understanding of the general theory.

Let me mention an example and pose some puzzles about it. I'm looking at algebras over R\mathbb{R}R. My go-to example of a homomorphism of algebras f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B is the inclusion i:R→Ci: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C}i:R→C.

So, f∗f^\astf∗ gives me the "underlying real vector space of a complex vector space", while f∗f_\astf∗​ gives me the "complexification of a real vector space":

f∗(V)=C⊗RVf_\ast(V) = \mathbb{C} \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} V f∗​(V)=C⊗R​V
f∗(W)={real-linear maps R→W}f^\ast(W) = \{ \text{real-linear maps } \mathbb{R} \to W \} f∗(W)={real-linear maps R→W}

Here's the puzzle:

  1. Given a real vector space VVV, what is the set of isomorphism classes in the homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ over VVV?

  2. Given a complex vector space WWW, what is the set of isomorphism classes in the homotopy fiber of f∗f_\astf∗​ over WWW?
I'm really just asking for any other, less category-ridden and I hope more easily understood, description of these two sets.
Both these sets are famous (in certain quarters anyway - famous enough to have Wikipedia pages), but they're also fairly easy to describe without knowing any of the known stuff.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I'm interested by the "explanation available on request" on what is an homotopy fiber.

The short answer is: the homotopy fiber of a functor F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X over a point xxx is the category of ways you can get xxx (up to isomorphism) by applying the functor FFF to some object of AAA. The "up to isomorphism" part is what makes it a homotopy fiber instead of an ordinary fiber.

In homotopy theory we are often interested in a map F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X between topological spaces, and then the homotopy fiber of a point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X consists of points a∈Aa \in Aa∈A that don't need to have F(a)=xF(a) = xF(a)=x "on the nose": instead, it's enough to have a continuous path from F(a)F(a)F(a) to xxx.

I hope you see that here we are using an analogy between

  • isomorphisms between objects in categories

and

  • paths between points in spaces.

This analogy is ultimately much more than an analogy, especially if we stick to categories that are just groupoids, or nnn-categories that are nnn-groupoids.

For puzzle 2, the homotopy fiber of of the complexification functor, I think the answer is given by the theory of Galois descent. This would say that the isomorphism classes of the homotopy fiber correspond to conjugations on the complex vector space VVV, i.e. maps r ⁣:V→Vr\colon V \to Vr:V→V such that r(z⋅v)=zˉ⋅r(v)r(z \cdot v)=\bar{z}\cdot r(v)r(z⋅v)=zˉ⋅r(v) and r(v+v′)=r(v)+r(v′)r(v+v')=r(v)+r(v')r(v+v′)=r(v)+r(v′).

The homotopy fiber is always non-empty: I can just choose a basis of VVV, take its R\mathbb{R}R-linear span in VVV. That gives me an R\mathbb{R}R-vector space WWW and the inclusion map induces an isomorphism F(W)→VF(W)\to VF(W)→V.
An isomorphism in the homotopy fiber would be an isomorphism fff of R\mathbb{R}R-vector spaces such that the triangle with F(f)F(f)F(f) on top and VVV at the bottom commutes.
The point is that this triangle is a diagram of complex vector spaces and C\mathbb{C}C-linear maps.
So it seems that an isomorphism class in the fiber over VVV is given by a choice of R\mathbb{R}R-subvector space of VVV that C\mathbb{C}C-spans VVV (this is also called an R\mathbb{R}R-form of VVV).

That is already a more down to earth formulation than saying "homtopy fiber". Theorem 2.14 in the notes linked above says that the R\mathbb{R}R-forms of VVV in turn correspond to conjugations. This correspondence is also pretty concrete.

Great answer, @Peter Arndt. I think we don't need to know Galois descent ahead of time to answer question 2). We can just figure out the answer from scratch. But it is indeed the sort of question Galois descent is designed to answer.

Let me answer question 1), which has a somewhat different flavor.

Let's think about what an object in a homotopy fiber of the forgetful functor

f∗:VectC→VectR f^\ast: \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} f∗:VectC​→VectR​

actually is. We start with a real vector space V∈VectRV \in \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}}V∈VectR​.

Intuitively, an object in the homotopy fiber over VVV is a way of making VVV into a complex vector space.

But following the definition, an object in the homotopy fiber over VVV is acually a complex vector space WWW whose underlying real vector space f∗(W)f^\ast(W)f∗(W) is equipped with an isomorphism to VVV, say

α:f∗(W)→V \alpha: f^\ast(W) \to Vα:f∗(W)→V

We need to reconcile our intuition with the definition!

Since WWW is a complex vector space, its underlying real vector space f∗(W)f^\ast(W)f∗(W) comes with a complex structure: a real-linear endomorphism JJJ with J2=−1J^2 = -1J2=−1. This is just multiplication by iii on WWW, as seen in the world of real vector spaces.

We can use the isomorphism α\alphaα to transport this complex structure from f∗(W)f^*(W)f∗(W) to VVV.

It's easy to use the complex structure on VVV to promote this real vector space to a complex vector space.

So indeed, an object in the homotopy fiber gives a way to make VVV into a complex vector space! But it seems to give more: this other vector space WWW, and this isomorphism α\alphaα.

To reconcile our intuition with the definition, we need to check that this extra stuff is just fluff.

"Fluff" is stuff that goes away when you switch to working in an equivalent category.

So, we should suspect that the homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ over VVV is equivalent to the category where:

  • objects are complex structures JJJ on VVV.
  • the only morphisms are identity morphisms.
We can do this by messing around with commutative diagrams - and importantly, the definition of morphism in the homotopy fiber, which I haven't used yet!
The set of complex structures on a real vector space VVV can be described even more explicitly.
It's empty if VVV is odd-dimensional.
So say VVV is even-dimensional. We might as well say V=R2nV = \mathbb{R}^{2n}V=R2n.

The group GL(2n,R)GL(2n,\mathbb{R})GL(2n,R) acts transitively on the set of complex structures, since for each J:R2n→R2nJ: \mathbb{R}^{2n} \to \mathbb{R}^{2n}J:R2n→R2n with J2J^2J2 we can find a basis for R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n in which JJJ is block diagonal with 2×22 \times 22×2 blocks of this form:

(0−110) \left( \begin{array}{cr} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array} \right) (01​−10​)
The stabilizer of the "standard" complex structure on R2n≅Cn\mathbb{R}^{2n} \cong \mathbb{C}^nR2n≅Cn is, by definition, the group of complex-linear transformations GL(n,C)GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(n,C).

So, the set of complex structures on R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n is isomorphic to

GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C) GL(2n,\mathbb{R})/GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C)
So that's our homotopy fiber - a very concrete answer to puzzle 1!
Note that in this case it's a discrete category, a mere set. I think that's because f∗f^\astf∗ is faithful - it's only forgetting structure, not stuff.

Using the insights we'd gain by carefully working through this example, we can become quite efficient at working out homotopy fibers, at least in similar cases. Frankly I just think

"All complex structures on R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n are the same up to a linear transformation of R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n, so GL(2n,R)GL(2n,\mathbb{R})GL(2n,R) acts transitively on the set of these complex structures, and the stabilizer is GL(n,C)GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(n,C), so the homotopy fiber is GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C)GL(2n,\mathbb{R})/GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C)."

This brings up another puzzle:

Puzzle 3: find an answer to Puzzle 2 in which we describe the homotopy fiber of "complexification"

f∗:VectR→VectCf_\ast : \mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{R} \to \mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{C} f∗​:VectR​→VectC​

as the quotient of some group by a subgroup.

By the way, in case it's helpful for anyone else, I found this resource helpful for understanding a bit more of the above example: Kobayashi S., Nomizu K. - Foundations of differential geometry. Vol.2., chapter 9, section 1 (pages 114-116).

John Baez said:

Note that in this case it's a discrete category, a mere set. I think that's because f∗f^\astf∗ is faithful - it's only forgetting structure, not stuff.

Faithful, and also conservative. In general, the homotopy fibers of a faithful functor are (equivalent to) posets. For instance, if UUU is the forgetful functor from topological spaces to sets, then the homotopy fiber of UUU over a set XXX is the poset of topologies on XXX, ordered by refinement. But when the functor is also conservative, these posets are equivalent to discrete sets.
Thanks! I always forget what a [[conservative functor]] is, because I say such a functor "reflects isomorphisms".

So I was just about to pose two more abstract puzzles, based on the example I just worked through - for people who like category theory more than concrete examples from algebra and geometry. (I've heard such people exist.)

Puzzle 4: Given a functor F:A→XF: \mathsf{A} \to \mathsf{X}F:A→X, find simple conditions under which all its homotopy fibers are sets - that is, discrete categories.

In this case we can really talk about the set of ways an object in X\mathsf{X}X comes from an object in A\mathsf{A}A.

Puzzle 5: Give further conditions under which the homotopy fiber of an object x∈Xx \in \mathsf{X}x∈X is, not only a set, but a set that's a quotient of easily described groups G/HG/HG/H .
But Mike answered Puzzle 4 better than I could. So let me fill in some details of his answer.

Say we have two objects in the homotopy fiber over x∈Xx \in \mathsf{X}x∈X, for example

a∈A,α:F(a)→x a \in \mathsf{A} , \alpha: F(a) \to x a∈A,α:F(a)→x

and

a′∈A,α′:F(a′)→x a' \in \mathsf{A} , \alpha': F(a') \to x a′∈A,α′:F(a′)→x

I never said what a morphism between them was. Well, I said it was the "obvious thing" - but what's that? Clearly it should start out being a morphism

f:a→a′f: a \to a'f:a→a′

This then gives a morphism

F(f):F(a)→F(a′)F(f) : F(a) \to F(a')F(f):F(a)→F(a′)

And this then has the opportunity to form a commutative triangle with

α:F(a)→x \alpha: F(a) \to x α:F(a)→x

and

α′:F(a′)→x \alpha': F(a') \to x α′:F(a′)→x

So, clearly we should demand that it does:

α′∘F(f)=α \alpha' \circ F(f) = \alpha α′∘F(f)=α
And so that's what a morphism in the homotopy fiber is: a morphism f:a→a′f: a \to a'f:a→a′ obeying α′∘F(f)=α \alpha' \circ F(f) = \alpha α′∘F(f)=α.
Now suppose FFF is faithful. Let's try to show the homotopy fiber of FFF is a preorder, i.e. there's at most one morphism fff between objects in the homotopy fiber.

We can always solve the above equation for F(f)F(f)F(f):

F(f)=α′−1∘αF(f) = \alpha'^{-1} \circ \alpha F(f)=α′−1∘α
So we know what F(f)F(f)F(f) must be. But if FFF is faithful this means we know what f:a→a′f: a \to a'f:a→a′ must be!

So we've shown

FFF faithful   ⟹  \implies⟹ the homotopy fibers of FFF are preorders.

Puzzle 6. Is the converse true?
(I haven't thought about this but it's an obvious question.)

Next suppose that FFF "reflects isomorphisms", i.e. is "conservative": both these terms mean that

F(f)F(f)F(f) is an isomorphism   ⟹  \implies⟹ fff is an isomorphism.

Not even using those conditions, whenever we have a morphism fff in the homotopy fiber over fff we always get

F(f)=α′−1∘α F(f) = \alpha'^{-1} \circ \alphaF(f)=α′−1∘α

so F(f)F(f)F(f) must be an isomorphism.
But when FFF reflect isomorphism this means that fff is an isomorphism!

So we've shown

FFF reflects isomorphisms   ⟹  \implies⟹ the homotopy fibers of FFF are groupoids.

This raises yet another puzzle I haven't thought about:

Puzzle 7: Is the converse true?

So now, if FFF is faithful and it reflects isomorphisms, the homotopy fibers of FFF are preorders and groupoids. This means that if there's a morphism between two objects in a homotopy fiber it's unique and it's an isomorphism. This implies that the homotopy fiber is equivalent to a discrete category!

So we've shown

FFF is faithful and reflects isomorphisms   ⟹  \implies⟹ the homotopy fibers of FFF are equivalent to discrete categories.

or less pedantically

FFF is faithful and reflects isomorphisms   ⟹  \implies⟹ the homotopy fibers of FFF are sets.

where I'm using "are" in the modern, hip mathematician's sense of the verb "to be".
So, I've pounded Puzzle 4 to death, and the pounding process made two more puzzles shoot out!

John Baez said:

So we've shown

FFF faithful   ⟹  \implies⟹ the homotopy fibers of FFF are preorders.

Puzzle 6. Is the converse true?

The converse isn't true. Consider the category ∙⇉∙\bullet\rightrightarrows\bullet∙⇉∙ and let FFF map both of the nontrivial morphisms to the unique map {0,1}→{0}\{0,1\}\to\{0\}{0,1}→{0} in Set. Any homotopy fiber is now a preorder, but the functor is not faithful.
However, the converse is true if FFF is a fibration or an opfibration.

Nice observations!

To me, the most important unsolved puzzle is Puzzle 5, which to me is the key to understanding a large class of homotopy fibers very concretely as [[homogeneous spaces]].

Puzzle 5 might be hard to understand if you didn't follow my example where I showed the homotopy fiber of the forgetful functor VectC→VectR\mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}}VectC​→VectR​ over R2n\R^{2n}R2n is GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C)GL(2n,\mathbb{R})/GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C).
So, if anyone is having trouble, just ask questions.

So for any functor F:A→XF:A\to XF:A→X and x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, the homotopy fiber over xxx has an action by the group AutD(x){\rm Aut}_D(x)AutD​(x). Namely, given an isomorphism F(a)≅xF(a) \cong xF(a)≅x, we can compose it with any automorphism of xxx to get another isomorphism F(a)≅xF(a) \cong xF(a)≅x. Thus, if FFF is faithful and conservative, so that this homotopy fiber is equivalent to a set, it is moreover an AutD(x){\rm Aut}_D(x)AutD​(x)-set. Hence, like any set with a group action, it is a disjoint union of orbits, each of which is a homogeneous space. And if the action happens to be transitive, then it is a single orbit, i.e. a homogeneous space.

Transitivity of the action means directly that if we have ϕ:F(a)≅x\phi : F(a) \cong xϕ:F(a)≅x and ϕ′:F(a′)≅x\phi' : F(a') \cong xϕ′:F(a′)≅x, there is ψ:a≅a′\psi : a\cong a'ψ:a≅a′ and χ:x≅x\chi : x\cong xχ:x≅x making a commutative square. But then χ\chiχ is uniquely determined by the other three data, and if this holds for all xxx then the hypothesis might as well be just that F(a)≅F(a′)F(a)\cong F(a')F(a)≅F(a′). So, if FFF is faithful and conservative, then its homotopy fibers are homogeneous spaces if it is injective on isomorphism classes.
The homogeneous space in question should then be AutD(x)/AutA(a){\rm Aut}_D(x) / {\rm Aut}_A(a)AutD​(x)/AutA​(a), for some a∈Aa\in Aa∈A such that F(a)≅xF(a) \cong xF(a)≅x.

:tada: YES! :tada:

So the extra condition we need to get this to work, beside FFF being faithful and conservative, is that it "creates isomorphisms". This is jargon for

F(a)≅F(a′)  ⟹  a≅a′ F(a) \cong F(a') \implies a \cong a' F(a)≅F(a′)⟹a≅a′

or in other words what Mike said: FFF is injective on isomorphism classes.

All three conditions hold in the case of our forgetful functor

VectC→VectR \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} VectC​→VectR​
It's faithful: two complex-linear maps between complex vector spaces are equal if the corresponding real-linear maps between the underlying real vector spaces are equal.
It's conservative: if the underlying real-linear map of a complex-linear map is an iso, the original complex-linear map was an iso.
And it creates isomorphisms: if the underlying real vector spaces of two complex vector spaces are isomorphic (= have the same dimension), then the same is true of the original complex vector spaces!
"Injective on isomorphism classes" feels like a weird condition, category-theoretically.

True! I've been bumping into it lately. It's probably worth checking out what happens to our homotopy fiber when that third condition is not true. We should still get something nice.

But anyway, first I just want to tell the lurking students that in this example, using your result, the homotopy fiber of R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n turns out to be

AutVectR(R2n)/AutVectC(Cn) \mathrm{Aut}_{\mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{R}} (\mathbb{R}^{2n}) / \mathrm{Aut}_{\mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{C}} (\mathbb{C}^{n}) AutVectR​​(R2n)/AutVectC​​(Cn)

which is better known as

GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C) \mathrm{GL}(2n,\mathbb{R}) / \mathrm{GL}(n,\mathbb{C}) GL(2n,R)/GL(n,C)

And this is a famous space: the space of complex structures on Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn. We can think of it as the space of linear maps

{J:Rn→Rn∣J2=−1} \{ J : \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^n \vert J^2 = -1 \}{J:Rn→Rn∣J2=−1}

Now, a while back @Peter Arndt answered Puzzle 2, which was: what are the homotopy fibers of the left adjoint to the forgetful functor I've just been talking about! This left adjoint is "complexification"

f∗:VectR→VectC f_\ast: \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} f∗​:VectR​→VectC​

(using my notation, which the topos theorists dislike). It sends any real vector space VVV to C⊗RV\mathbb{C} \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} V C⊗R​V.

@Peter Arndt showed that the homotopy fiber over Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn of this left adjoint is the set of nnn-dimensional real subspaces V⊆CnV \subseteq \mathbb{C}^nV⊆Cn with the property that V+iV=CnV + iV = \mathbb{C}^nV+iV=Cn.

But it would be nice if we could describe this, too, as a quotient of groups. So:

Puzzle 8: Is complexification faithful? Is it conservative? Is it injective on isomorphism classes?

John Baez said:

It's probably worth checking out what happens when that condition is not true. We should still get something nice.

I guess what we get is the disjoint union of homogeneous spaces ∐aAutX(x)/AutA(a)\coprod_a {\rm Aut}_X(x) / {\rm Aut}_A(a)∐a​AutX​(x)/AutA​(a), where aaa ranges over one object in each isomorphism class whose image is the isomorphism class of xxx.
That's what I bet too! It's sort of a slightly groupoidy analogue of a homogeneous space.
But the "numerator" is the same for each summand; only the denominator varies.

I have some important examples where this comes up, coming from representation theory. So far my examples here concern the real representations of the algebras R↪C\mathbb{R} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{C}R↪C. But if we change its square root of -1 to a square root of +1, C\mathbb{C}C would turn into R⊕R\mathbb{R} \oplus \mathbb{R}R⊕R. If we copied our story using the inclusion R↪R⊕R\mathbb{R} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R} \oplus \mathbb{R}R↪R⊕R, we would get nonisomorphic R⊕R \mathbb{R} \oplus \mathbb{R}R⊕R that have isomorphic underlying real vector spaces.

Also known as a not-necessarily-transitive GGG-set...

This is interesting! I'm working on understanding some of the things said above. Since questions are welcome, I thought I would ask for some explanation/clarification.

I'll begin by stating what I think I understand so far.

  • Let f∗:VectC→VectRf^*: \mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{C} \to \mathsf{Vect}_\mathbb{R}f∗:VectC​→VectR​ be our forgetful functor of interest, sending each complex vector space to its underlying real vector space.
  • Let WWW be a complex vector space. Then f∗(W)f^*(W)f∗(W) has a "complex structure" on it. That is, it has an endomorphism JJJ with J2=−1f∗(W)J^2= -1_{f^*(W)}J2=−1f∗(W)​. We know this because the real-linear map that sends vvv to iviviv for any vvv in f∗(W)f^*(W)f∗(W) will provide such an endomorphism.

But this is a fundamental result in 'Klein geometry'.

Felix Klein massively generalized Euclidean and various known non-Euclidean geometries by saying that you get different kinds of geometry from different groups. To do geometry you first choose a group G of symmetries. Then any subgroup H will preserve some type of 'geometrical figure' like a point or line, and G/H will be the set of all figures of that type.

So the idea is that if VVV is a real vector space, and we suddenly pretend we can multiply guys in VVV by complex numbers - the sort of thing physicists do without blinking an eye, since nobody has ever stopped a physicist from doing this - we are actually replacing VVV by its complexification, C⊗RV\mathbb{C} \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} VC⊗R​V.

But more to the point, complexification is a functor

VectR→VectC \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} VectR​→VectC​

that is left adjoint to the 'forgetful functor'

VectC→VectR \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} VectC​→VectR​

that foolishly forgets we can multiply by complex numbers, and thinks of a complex vector space as a mere real vector space with dimension twice as big - like thinking of Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn as R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n.

You've said you haven't got the hang of adjoint functors yet, but the best way to get it is to keep seeing examples of pairs of functors that go back and forth between 2 categories: often the right adjoint involves "forgetting stuff you knew" while the left adjoint involves "puffing something up to make it better".

Here the right adjoint

VectC→VectR \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} VectC​→VectR​

forgets how to multiply by complex numbers and turns a complex vector space into a real vector space, while the left adjoint

VectR→VectC \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{R}} \to \mathsf{Vect}_{\mathbb{C}} VectR​→VectC​

puffs up our real vector space by "going ahead and pretending we know how to multiply vectors by complex numbers".
